Come Arethuse come, for nere had we,</br>At any time a greater need of thee.</br>No Lawrell now, but Nettle's best to grace</br>Our Laureat Poet see his uncouth face,</br>Unapt for poesie:  his strange disguise,</br>Onely addrest (in Verse) to Temporize:</br>Now Parasites prove Poets, and expresse</br>Their oyly workes:  for what is more or lesse</br>Dilated on, is consecrate to men,</br>That are the greatest:  O what need is then,</br>To thee (deere Arthuse) that didst frame,</br>A Poet to the nature of his name?</br>No time-observing smooth fac'd sycophant,</br>No strange conceited Asse whose Element</br>Is to insinuate under the shade</br>Of a great Mounseyrs elbow, thour't prov'd Jade</br>To thy profession, not a saffron band,</br>But like a roaring boye, can make thee stand</br>And yeeld observance to him:  silly foole,</br>That Artlesse idiots should bring to schoole,</br>The best of Muses, thou that once wast borne,</br>Not as our great Acteons, to the horne</br>Of their dishonour, (being of joy bereft)</br>Leaving to others what themselves have left.</br>(Worse by degrees then was that Phoebus Car,</br>Which Phaeton by rash attempts did marre:</br>And cleere dissolves) lasse see thy Trophies torne,</br>Thy statues razed:  and that Mount forlorne</br>Which first possest the Muses:  now no wreath</br>Can be hung up to memorize the death</br>Of any great man, why for vertues due,</br>Bids every Poet (in his verse) speake true</br>Of such as are deceased:  its true, who then</br>Speaking no more then truth, can praise such men,</br>As rather were then liv'd?  being, but not</br>In reall essence, las what fame is got</br>By such as write of these (whose onely good)</br>Is to averre they were of Noble bloud.</br>But so much disproportion'd to their name,</br>As what they seem'd, they seldome were the same.</br>The same; O noe, their garish ornament,</br>Their wanton guise, their Love-sicke complement,</br>Their strange distractions, their deformed state,</br>Transform'd from English to Italienate,</br>Expresse small comfort to a Poets penne,</br>Which onely should delight in shewing them</br>Unto the worlds eye, whose fame succeedes,</br>And makes them Noble by Heroicke deedes,</br>Drawen from the line of Honour:  but how farre</br>Seeme Poets in these latter times to erre?</br>Who write not for respect, or due esteeme,</br>Had to their owne profession, but to gaine</br>The favour of a great one, this it is,</br>Gives priviledge to men that doe amisse:</br>Such be our ranke of Poets now adayes,</br>As they adorne th' Immerited with praise</br>Above desert.  Hence is it that we bring</br>The Art of Poetry to Ballading.</br>Hence is it, that the Courtier may intend</br>A strange pretended project for no end,</br>Save to augment's expence, a suites begun,</br>Which makes a silly Farmer quite undone,</br>Without all hope of composition:  l'asse</br>That such transgressions should so freely passe,</br>Without controulement.  Many we have heere,</br>That can compose their Verse, but in a sphere</br>So different to the time, as they descry</br>Their want of braines to each judicious eye.</br>Yea some I know are Poets in this time</br>Who write of swains, might write as well of swine,</br>For th' profit of their labours is so small,</br>As t'were farre better not to write at all,</br>Then to consume such pretious time in vaine,</br>About a fruitlesse, and desertlesse straine:</br>Better indeed:  when in their Makers sight,</br>They must accomptants be of what they write,</br>Whose eyes be purer, and extension beare,</br>Above th' Dimension of a common sphere.</br>Yet ranke I not (as some men doe suppose)</br>These worthlesse swaines amongst the laies of those</br>Time-honour'd Shepheards (for they still shall be)</br>As well they merit) honoured of mee,</br>Who beare a part, like honest faithfull swaines,</br>On witty Wither never-withring plaines,</br>For these (though seeming Shepheards) have deserv'd,</br>To have their names in lasting Marble carv'd:</br>Yea this I know I may be bold to say,</br>Thames ner'e had swans that song more sweet than they.</br>It's true I may avow't, that nere was song,</br>Chanted in any age by swains so young,</br>With more delight then was perform'd by them,</br>Pretily shadow'd in a borrowed name.</br>And long may Englands Thespian springs be known</br>"By lovely Wither and by bonny Browne,"</br>Whilest solid Seldon, and their Cuddy too,</br>Sing what our (Swaines of old) could never doe.</br>Yea I do hope, sith they so well can write,</br>Of Shep-heards sport, and of the fields delight.</br>That when they come to take a view of th' Court,</br>(As some have done) and have bin mew'd up for't,</br>They'l tell her freely, (as full well they may)</br>That in their Judgements, after due survay,</br>Of th' Court and th' Cottage, they may well maintain,</br>Vices in the Court, but vertues in the Swaine;</br>And happy be those Authors which doe give</br>Vertue and vice their titles, they shall live</br>In spite of Envie, when such men as teach</br>That such be onely vertuous as be rich,</br>Shall lye inter'd, where fame shall never finde them,</br>For such doe seldome leave a name behind them.</br>Lasse they must dye and perish, so must we,</br>Nor can we gaine ought of eternity:</br>Save that we live, Oh then how blest are they</br>That spend their life in weighing of their daies.</br>But of professants, which compose their song</br>To a strange descant!  this Ile say they wrong</br>Flowrie Parnassus, where such used to be,</br>As in themselves made one set company.</br>These sung not what they knew not, but in Verse,</br>What time had taught them they use to rehearse,</br>And to reduce it to one perfect forme,</br>Striving by proper figures to adorne</br>Ech worke, ech composition:  but lasse now</br>How farre's that alteration?  where we know</br>Lest that we write, adding to our estate</br>(Begg'd meerely) by a great mans Dedicate.</br>Heere is no substance, but a simple peece</br>Of gaudy Rhetoricke:  Which if it please,</br>Yeelds th' Author dear-contentment:  thus we straine</br>The Muses Text for a peculiar gaine</br>Unto our selves:  hence is it vice abides,</br>(And lording-like in silken foot-cloath rides.)</br>Hence is it Land-lords make their tenants slaves:</br>Hence is it waste-goods ope their fathers graves:</br>Hence is it Mammonists adore their golde:</br>Hence is't the impious to perdition solde:</br>Hence Sacriledge a priviledge obtaines:</br>Hence th' sneking Lawyer by his Clyent gaines:</br>Hence th' Politician, what so ere befall,</br>Will to his trade and shew a Machivell.</br>Hence imposts rise extortions violence,</br>Graced by men that have most eminence.</br>Hence Sergeants walk unfronted (though they know it)</br>No friend is worse then Sergeant to a Poet.</br>Hence painted faces (like ill wine in caske)</br>Shrow'd their deform'd complexions under maske.</br>Hence curious Courtiers, gorgeously arrayd,</br>Weare more upon their backe then ere was paide:</br>Hence th' baudie Pandor, servile to his whore,</br>And hence the Baude that keeps the traders dore;</br>Hence base informers take their borrowed light,</br>Living like Owles that use to flie by night:</br>Hence wanton Prodigals that spend their state,</br>And 'gin repentance when it is too late.</br>Hence young and old, hence each in their degree,</br>Challenge to them a due Monopolie.</br>O how Minervas temple's now disgrac't,</br>By th' skum of Poetry!  she that was plac't</br>Once like th' Ephesian Queene in a pure shrine</br>Of honour and delight, now's forc't to pine</br>And languish in her bewty, being deprest,</br>By such men most, whom she suspecteth lest.</br>Unpiniond Muses (such as nere could flie)</br>Further then unplum'd birds now presse as high</br>As Eagles; which by the Colour you may know,</br>As eminent and cleere as Flaccus Crow:</br>These steale selected flowres from others wit,</br>And yet protest their nature brookes not it,</br>They are (for both) so invented by their art,</br>Making their pen the displayer of their heart.</br>They brooke no Brocage, yet has workes in presse,</br>Which they are guiltlesse of?  but this were lesse,</br>Worthy reproofe, if in their gleaned lines,</br>Like our age Criticks they would curbe these times</br>For petulancie:  but so vaine be they,</br>As they runne still in that high beaten way</br>Of errour, by directing men amisse,</br>Penning whole volumes of licentiousnesse,</br>Descanting on my Ladies Rosie lip,</br>Her Cinthian eie, her bending front, her trip,</br>Her bodies motion, notion of her time,</br>All which they weave up in a baudy Rime.</br>For since there's no observance, Accent neither</br>(Sith sence and accent seldome goe together.)</br>O what aspersions doe these lay on her,</br>Who beares the onely native character.</br>Of her deere issues merit, shee I meane,</br>Without whose nourishment we had not been,</br>She without whose embrace, the solid earth,</br>Had quite interr'd the honour of our birth:</br>She without whom we have no biding place,</br>No mansion, no repose:  she by whose grace</br>We are inhabitants, planted in rest,</br>Sucking pure milke out of her tender brest.</br>She whose our Guardian governing our state</br>Shoring our weaknesse, arming us 'gainst fate,</br>Guiding our path-lesse passage, brething life</br>Into our dulnesse:  midiating strife,</br>Because (a peacefull mother) chering us</br>With solace, when deprest, tricking our Muse,</br>With seemly subjects (that whil'st shepheards sing)</br>Of rurall pastimes, midst their sonneting,</br>The graver ranke might compositions make,</br>Not for themselves but for their countries sake:</br>Alasse poore countrie; where is all that store</br>Of divine wits that thou hast bred before?</br>Where is that Quint-essence of poesie,</br>That in (fore-times) was wont to breath on thee:</br>Like a coole Zephirus?  Hybles pure mount,</br>Renowm'd in former ages and that Fount,</br>Of sacred Castalie lie desolate.</br>For they with theirs have lost their former state</br>Of Greatnesse:  no proportion nor no flower</br>Decks, with a dasie Border, that sweet Bower</br>Where Cinthia us'd to revell:  but as th' port</br>Of house-keeping is now transport'd to Court,</br>"Leaving their Country-houses, which men looke</br>And gase at long ere they can see them smoke:"</br>So fruitfull Hesperie, which us'd to be</br>The Ren-de vou for sacred poesie</br>Leving to be her selfe, shuts up her dore?</br>Hence is the bankrout poet becom'd poore:</br>Hence is't hee's forc't to write not for the ease</br>Of his owne minde (but as his Patrons please.)</br>Hence ist that errors must be Vertues deem'd,</br>Because, poore Poet, its by Fate ordain'd,</br>That if he will not humour, he must sterve:</br>"For Great-men love not heare what they deserve."</br>How jealous be our times of their deserts,</br>When they suppresse the eminence of arts?</br>Making them speechlesse whereas we do see,</br>If persons were dispos'd as they should be;</br>Their sincere conscience (like a brazen wall)</br>Might beare them up what ever should befall.</br>Then might our Satyre mixe his inke with gal,</br>But with his mixture do no hurt at all.</br>Then might our scepticke give his judgement free,</br>Yet do small harme to mens integritie.</br>Then might the Lawyer pleade without offence;</br>Not seare his Conscience with a faire pretence</br>Of doing good, when his corrupted will</br>Under pretence of good, acts what is ill.</br>Then might the divels Factors live like men,</br>That have a god, nor for the hundred ten;</br>Receiving with advantage need'd they pay,</br>A greater summe at that same latter daie,</br>When due accompts are had:  O usurie</br>That art the Cities scourge, how much have we</br>Occasion to proscribe thee from our land,</br>Since by thy meanes have we felt heavens hand</br>More heavy and revenging then before,</br>Whose wrath has vialls ever laid in store</br>To punish impious men:  its thou (fowle sin)</br>Which hast hal'd downe the infection we have seene</br>Rage in this famous Ile:  its thou whose hight</br>Hath turn'd our day of comfort to a night</br>Of great affliction:  for who more can be</br>Afflicted in himselfe, then inwardly</br>Feeling the worme of Conscience gnawing him</br>Torment consorting with that birth of sinne</br>Wherein he's nurtured:  alas poore Ile!</br>That thou shouldst foster such as do defile</br>Thy once renowmed borders with the hate</br>Of a supernall power, making thy state</br>Pray to oppression, vassalling thy fame</br>(Which once was glorious) to thy odious name</br>Of miserie:  Great Albion now is growne</br>Poore in her selfe, because what is her owne</br>She cannot use but in depraved wise,</br>Makes her selfe subject to all forraine eyes</br>As vices spectacle:  O that the blisse</br>Which we enjoy by minds Synderysis</br>Th' refined part of man, should soyled be</br>By th' worst of ils the staine of usury?</br>And who'le inveigh against it, few or none,</br>For miser Nature hardly leaves us one,</br>That can securely speake against this ill</br>So generall is the poison of our will:</br>For (deere Pernassus now is so opprest)</br>It dare not speake for feare that interest,</br>Should be demaunded by the Usurer</br>To whom it stands engag'd:  this is the fate</br>That Poets have, to leave more wit then state</br>To their posteritie:  O impious time!</br>When worst of Fortune followes wits divine;</br>When noble actions motive in their spirit,</br>Can leave nought to their Issue to inherit:</br>Save their poore fathers papers, monuments</br>Scarce worth respect:  how weakes the Element</br>Which Poets are compos'd of, when one frowne</br>Sent from a great mans visage can keepe downe</br>Their best invention?  silly poesie,</br>That (though free borne, art forc't to slavery,</br>And undeserv'd subjection:  pittie it is,</br>That best of merit should shut up her wish;</br>And dew expectance in no other booke,</br>Save in a skrew'd face or a writhed looke;</br>Unfit to entertaine an Art divine</br>Which is exprest in that poore Muse of thine.</br>Come, come, great regent of that sacred quire,</br>Come in thy selfe and so our soules inspire</br>With Arts Elixir and with spirit toe,</br>That we may do with boldnes what we do:</br>Erect our aged fortunes make them shine</br>(Not like the foole in's foot-cloath) but like Time,</br>Adorn'd with true experiments which may</br>Convert our odious night to glorious day.</br>Let not Ambition mounted in her state</br>Passe uncontrol'd:  care not for getting hate:</br>"For honest minds are best approved still,</br>Let not these painted blocks of Juvenal,"</br>Which for their cloaths are most admir'd of al</br>Stand unreproov'd:  let not their dangling plume</br>So daunt thee, as thou dare not well presume</br>To blazon their defects, speake what thou seest</br>And care not who be pleas'd, or who displeas'd.</br>Let not moth-eaten Avarice appeare</br>In this deere Ile, without her Character:</br>Lash me the Symonist, who though precise</br>In shew, can geld his Parsons Benifice.</br>Gall me (our graine-engrossers) moulds of th' earth,</br>That in their plentie laugh at others dearth.</br>Rouse me the Atheist, let's security</br>Heare th' judgement of supernall majestie</br>Thundring against him:  let th' lascivious</br>Know their bed-broking sin, how odious</br>Their sensuall meetings are to his pure eyes,</br>Who even the secrets of our hearts espies,</br>Searching our reines, examining our hearts,</br>Discussing each intention (and all parts)</br>That have a working faculty:  Even he</br>That well approves of morall poesie,</br>He that confirmes the motions of our minde,</br>And breath's upon them if to good inclinde.</br>Let not sin-tempting wanton Meremaids rest</br>Without due censure, who with naked brest,</br>Attractive eye, and garish Complement</br>Ensnare our fond unwary Innocent:</br>These are those Babell publique prostitutes,</br>Lures to damnation, Romane Catamites,</br>Inventresses of pleasures, pensive still</br>To doe whats good, but frolike to doe ill.</br>O London how thy Vanity abounds,</br>Glorying in that which thy renowne confounds.</br>Traduced fashions from the Dutch to French,</br>From French to Spanish, and not longer since,</br>Then yesterday, blush at thy sinne for shame,</br>That Albion (by thy meanes) should lose her name,</br>And habit too:  see, see, how farre thou'rt gone,</br>Beyond thy selfe, that there's no fashion knowne,</br>In forraine Courts, deform'd howsoere it be,</br>But by transportance it doth come to thee.</br>Lasse how immodest art thou to expresse,</br>Thy selfe so much by others fashions lesse?</br>How strangely Metamorphis'd to partake,</br>For Angells forme, the most deformed shape,</br>That Countries can bring out:  O pittie tis</br>That Albions much admir'd Metropolis,</br>Should make those which admir'd her now to hate</br>Her vaine condition (introduc'd by state</br>Too plentifull:  Here you Hesperian wits</br>May you have subject more then well befits</br>A modest pen:  for nere was any time</br>More prone to ill:  no Region, countrey, clime,</br>Province, Isle, Regiment so truly blest</br>With all earths bounties, yet hath lesse exprest,</br>Of gratitude:  here Satirists resort,</br>And make an ample coment on the Court,</br>Where thou shalt write, som's wanton, others vaine,</br>Ambitious some, others doe covet gaine</br>By servile meanes:  some beggars, yet who dare</br>Write in these daies that any such there are.</br>Then (my sharp tooth'd Satire) frame thy ditty</br>In the same forme, unrip the Crimes of th' Citty</br>With a sterne brow:  tell the purple Magistrate,</br>How he has rais'd himselfe to great estate</br>By others ruine:  such as Mercers are,</br>Tell them darke shops have got away ill ware,</br>Such as be Gold-smiths, and are dangerous,</br>Call them the Silver-smith of Ephesus.</br>Long live Diana, but no longer then</br>By their Diana they doe reape a gaine.</br>Such as be Brokers, tell them their profession,</br>Is not to be a knave o' th first edition.</br>But as those garments which are brought to them,</br>Use to be worne before by other men:</br>Even so they broke their vices and receive</br>Som crimes wrapt up i' th garmets which they have,</br>Tell them of Wapping, bid them thankfull be,</br>That there is Justice had for Piracie:</br>For if that were not (it may well be said)</br>Many their shops would be unfurnished,</br>But in the Country now my Muse shall be,</br>For brooke shee'le not a Brokers Company.</br>Here shalt thou see th' picture of Avarice,</br>Thin-cheek'd, raw-bon'd, faint-breath, and hollow-eyes.</br>Nose-dropping, rhewme-destilling, driveling mouth</br>Hand-shaking, haire down-falling, th' misers cough,</br>Legs goutie, knees unweldy, hand on cruch,</br>Eies in his bosome, gasing on his pouch,</br>His labour torment, rest he cannot take,</br>When all are sleeping, he is forc't to wake:</br>His Eies are ever ope, for riches keepe</br>His eies unclosed:  The miser cannot sleepe.</br>He's his owne anguish, such an impious elfe,</br>Thats ill to all, but worst unto himselfe.</br>He has not bookes whereon to meditate,</br>Onely a debt booke and an Alminake.</br>The one's for forfeitures, where he will pore,</br>And daie by day travers them ore and ore:</br>Th' other's his Enterlude that yeelds him mirth,</br>Seeing predictions of the next yeeres dearth.</br>Hope of a deerer Sommer then last was</br>Unseasoned harvest:  O these hopes surpasse</br>All others, Heere the Miser sets his eie,</br>And when he does these strange prenotions spie,</br>He kisses th' booke, sweares the profession's rare,</br>And wishes all hee reades such subjects were.</br>This Cormorant engrosseth all his graine,</br>Makes his barnes greater by a secret traine</br>Brings ore his neighbours sonne to set his hand,</br>Unto a sale, and so joynes land to land.</br>This wicked ulcer that corrupts the state,</br>Nere thinkes of death, till that it be too late.</br>His gold's his God, yet use it cannot he,</br>But in expression of his miserie:</br>Which puts the poore Miser to a double paine,</br>By telling it and putting't up againe.</br>But now (my nimble Satyre) for to thee</br>Tends this impolisht peece of poesie:</br>How wilt thou taxe, or where wilt thou begin</br>With thy tart phrase, to stinge and nettle him?</br>Thou must be bitter (for in greatest grieves)</br>And festered wounds we use no lenitives</br>To mollefie, but corrasives to gall:</br>And of all griefes this is the great'st of all.</br>By it we are degenerate and live,</br>As such as can receive, bnt cannot give</br>To Nature competence:  Come my deare Mate</br>Ile tell thee how to cure their desperate state;</br>Which in few words least that thy memory faile,</br>Ile speake my minde unto thee in a tale.

It chaunc't upon a time (and well might be</br>For such like chances fall on miserie,)</br>A pinch-gut Miser fell extreamely sicke,</br>So, as at last his Conscience gan to pricke,</br>And tell him of's oppression, wheresoere</br>He turn'd his eyes, he saw damnation there.</br>Sleepe could he not, his sicknesse was too great,</br>Nor hope for ought, his conscience did so threate</br>And terrifie his soule:  thus lay this wretch</br>Poore in his spirit, though to the world rich;</br>Faine would he oft desire himselfe confest.</br>But cause he was falne out with Parish priest</br>About a Tith-pigge, he deferr'd the time,</br>And would in no case suffer this Divine</br>To minister due comfort to his state</br>All woe begone:  so great was th' Misers hate:</br>For though he were afflicted, yet would he</br>Up-braide the Parson full irreverently,</br>Calling him hedge priest, belly-god (nay more)</br>That like a Thiefe, he came not in at dore,</br>But in at windowe to his Benefice;</br>And that he knew the practice and device</br>Of him and's Patron:  who that th' law might by</br>Dispensed with in case of Symonie,</br>Sold him a horse (that whatsoere should fall,)</br>The price might pay for th' Benefice and all;</br>This would he say, concluding merrily,</br>Sir Priest you come more for my pigge then me,

Silent the Parson was, for well he knew,</br>The Miser spoke no more then what was true</br>Onely he wisht such neighbours as he had</br>Present to pray for him, for he was mad,</br>And that by all appearance it was like</br>That his disease had made him lunaticke:</br>Thus every day his sicknesse did encrease,</br>Bereft of comfort, conscience sweetest peace,</br>Without all hope of health or here or there,</br>(For th' worm of conscience follows every where.)</br>There's no evasion left:  where ere we goe</br>She will attend us in our weale and woe.</br>You heard confest he would, but as tis true,</br>A miser loves not him that craves his due:</br>So to such men this censure stands for iust,</br>They love their Conscience rest lesse then their rust.</br>What should he doe?  the Parson now is gone,</br>And he unto himselfe is left alone</br>T' expostulate with death:  his sinnes did grieve him</br>But now the most when all his friends do leave him;</br>Torment belowe, judgement he sees above,</br>Witnesse within him, that will duly prove</br>What he has done on earth (thus all in one</br>Make up a consort in his dying mone:</br>Yet as a ship ore-burdend with her freight</br>Sinking before, sayls bravely, being made light;</br>Or as the Ocean beats from shelfe to shelfe,</br>(Sea-sicke god-wot) till she hath purg'd herselfe.</br>So this sur-charged soule rowl's here and there,</br>And yet to comfort is no whit the neere,</br>Till that same lastage of corruption be</br>Exempted quite:  then sleepes she quietly.</br>Confesse he must, but to no Priest, that's vaine:</br>But unto one cleere of another straine;</br>Shall I tell Satire?  yes, thou needs must know it,</br>And this he was; a thrid-bare neighbouring Poet:</br>Who after dew confession made to him</br>Of every act, and each peculiar sinne,</br>Extortion, Violence and Injurie,</br>Pressing of Orphanes, biting usurie,</br>Forfeitures taken, forged bills, at last</br>He makes confession how a Poet past</br>His pikes:  who once was of a faire estate,</br>But after had no prospect but a grate:</br>O, quoth the Poet, that was ill in you;</br>O (quoth the Miser) I doe know its true:</br>But with remorce I now lament his fall,</br>Which 'mongst the rest afflicts me most of all.</br>Wherefore good Sir, poure out your prayers for me,</br>That in distast of my impiety</br>Languishing sore, I may be cheerd in state,</br>Dying in hope, that now lies desperate.</br>The faire conditio'nd Poet, though he had heard</br>How ill his owne profession got reward,</br>By this hard-harted Miser; yet did he</br>Scorne his revenge should in affliction be:</br>Streight he retires himselfe a pretty space,</br>Chusing for's Orisons a private place,</br>Which being done, to cheere the drooping man,</br>With hands heav'd up, his praiers he thus began.

Powerfull Jehovah, King of Heaven and Earth,</br>That giv'st to all things living life and birth.</br>Thou that protects each thing which thou hast made,</br>And so preserv's it, as it cannot fade.</br>Before the time prefin'd:  thou that wilt have</br>Mercy on such as thou dost meane to save.</br>Looke on this wretch (that lies all woe begon)</br>If so thou thinke hees worthy looking on:</br>Great is thy mercy, so it needs must be,</br>If thou wilt save such Miscreants as he.</br>But what thou meanes to doe, he faine would know,</br>Whether he must ascend, or fall below:</br>That he provision may according make,</br>And fit himselfe for th' Voyage he must take.</br>For if to heaven, he needs the lesse prepare,</br>Because he knowes all needfull things be there.</br>But much he fear'd, and so feare other some,</br>Mongst which my selfe, that there be nere shall come,</br>But if to hell (the likelier place o' th two)</br>He does desire, that thou wouldst this allow.</br>He may have so much respite as prepare,</br>The Bonds of all such Prodigalls be there:</br>That what he could not cancell here so well</br>On earth, may there be cancelled in hell.</br>The cause is this (as it to me appeares)</br>Lest that those spend-thrifts fall about his eares,</br>When they shall see him, which that he may stay,</br>He'le cancell th' Bonds, though't be long after day</br>Or this's the cause as he was impious here,</br>He meanes to prove an honest Devill there.</br>"That Time to Times-successors may bring forth,</br>Hell made him better than he was on Earth."

Much more he praide, but I doe rather chuse,</br>(Satyre) to make of all his praiers an use,</br>That when the use shall well expressed be,</br>Thou maist apply the Benefit to thee.</br>Sir [quoth the Poet] I my praiers have made,</br>Have you, (replyed he,) as one dismayed,</br>Yes sir, and by them so my zeale enforc't,</br>As I prevaild, though it was long time first,</br>For know an apparision came to me</br>With a shrill voice, which bad me say to thee:</br>If thou wile first a restitution make,</br>And render up what thou by Fraud didst take,</br>From any man, but chiefly what thou tooke</br>From th' Poet:  next, deliver up thy booke</br>Of all Accounts, great'st cause of thy despaire,</br>To thy Confessour, and make him thy heyre.</br>Thou shalt have health for this, it bad me tell,</br>But if thou wilt not thou art markt for hell,</br>For Hell, no marry I take keyes and state,</br>I will not buy wealth at so deere a rate.</br>If thou my pretty Satyre couldst reclayme,</br>A miser thus, I'de thanke thee for the same.</br>But all too long I have enforc't thee stay,</br>Vice calleth thee, and Time drawes me away.</br>
